> 
> "Incremental Evolution of Trainable Neural Networks that are
> Backwards Compatible" Fifth  IASTED International Conference on
> Artificial Intelligence and Applications (AIA 2006), February 2006
> 
> I have added it to the group.  It is a Word document, 6 pages.
>

> cite it.

>>>> From: cpchristenson <cpchristenson@...>
>>>> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>>> Date: Mon, 20 Nov 2006 16:54:31 -0000
>>>> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>>> Subject: [neat] Re: Some questions from beginner in NEAT
>>>> 
>>>> I still read, just never comment.  I did have success combining
>>>> evolution and learning.  However, unlike what you described, my
>>>> thesis included the learning within the life of the network
> rather
>>>> than after the evolution is complete.  So, evolution would
> create a
>>>> network, then that network would learn to perform a task, then
> it
>>>> was evaluated based on its ability to learn the task.  The
> learned
>>>> weights were NOT passed onto the next generation.  The idea was
> to
>>>> evolve a network that was better at learning.  I was able to
> show
>>>> this was possible using the task of learning to solve
> polynomials.
>>>> A very simple example, but functional.
>>>> 
>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@>
> wrote:
>>>>> 
>>>>> I know people have combined NEAT with BP in the past.  For
>>>> example,
>>>>> Chris Christenson had some success with it, but I'm not sure
> he's
>>>>> still reading this group.
>>>>> 
>>>>> In any case, the number of generations (and hence the length of
>>>>> time) it takes to solve a problem depends on problem
> difficulty,
>>>> so
>>>>> it's difficult to give an accurate estimate, but 7 hours is
>>>> probably
>>>>> a reasonable expectation for the problem you cite.
>>>>> 
>>>>> In fact, supervised classification problems tend to be faster
> than
>>>>> control problems since they don't involve a domain simulator,
> so
>>>> you
>>>>> can expect it to be possibly a lot faster.  However, if you
> use BP
>>>>> you have to factor in the time that adds to each evaluation,
>>>>> depending how you fold it into your procedure.
>>>>> 
>>>>> I'm also guessing you will not need two hidden layers of 8
> hidden
>>>>> nodes each to solve your problem.  NEAT usually discovers that
> it
>>>>> takes a lot less than you expect to solve problems that seem
> like
>>>>> they should be difficult.
>>>>> 
>>>>> Finally, NEAT has been applied to real world industrial
> problems
>>>> in
>>>>> simulation, but I'm not sure if it's been literally used in
> e.g a
>>>>> real factory or something like that.  But a 300 instance
>>>>> classification sounds fairly straightforward.
>>>>> 
>>>>> ken
>>>>> 
>>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "aimike002" <aimike002@> wrote:
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Sorry , just to clarify for (3) if we took an example with
>>>>>> say 300 training samples, with say 100 samples in the test
> set.
>>>>>> Just to try and get an idea.
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> Mike
>>>>>> 
>>>>>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "aimike002" <aimike002@> wrote:
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Hi I'm taking a look for possibly using in for my Masters
>>>>> project,
>>>>>>> which  needs evolving the architecture for a neural net for a
>>>>> real
>>>>>>> world application.
>>>>>>> I have read some of Ken Stanley's papers on the web but
> beyond
>>>>> that
>>>>>>> I'm a beginner, so if I may ask some beginner's questions:
>>>>>>> 1) I think my neural net may be evolved using GAs , but fine
>>>>> tuned to
>>>>>>> optimise using standard BP (ie hybrid approach). Has anybody
>>>>> else been
>>>>>>> down that path using NEAT, taking e.g. the weights evolved
>>>> using
>>>>> NEAT
>>>>>>> & feeding them into some standard BP software?
>>>>>>> 2) Has NEAT been used in any 'real world'/industrial
>>>>> applications yet?
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> and a 'how long is a piece of string question'...
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> 3)  As yet  have no feel for how long the evolution might
>>>> take.
>>>>> I've
>>>>>>> ran a few of the downloaded sample executables they seem to
>>>> take
>>>>> quite
>>>>>>> a while to run. My neural net has 8 inputs, one output and if
>>>> we
>>>>> guess
>>>>>>> at a final neural net of 2 hidden layers with 8 nodes per
>>>> layer.
>>>>> If we
>>>>>>> used say a 2GHz PC doing nothing else - could we guess at 7
>>>> hours
>>>>>>> (i.e. an overnight run) to evolve or is it more likely to be
>>>>> several
>>>>>>> days? Would appreciate any best guesses or experience on
> this.
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Thanks in advance
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>> Mike
>>>>>>> 
>>>>>>
